Topics: Informational Text - Craft & Structure/Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Describe the overall structure (e.g., chronology, comparison, cause/effect, problem/solution) of events, ideas, concepts, or information in a text or part of a text.
Content: Which statement best describes the structure of the second paragraph of the passage?

A.Choice: It compares drawing a flipbook to making a clay animation film.

Key.Rationale: The paragraph explains how making a clay animation film is “similar to drawing a flipbook.”

B.Choice: It describes how a flipbook can be turned into a clay animation film.

Key.Rationale: The paragraph does not describe how a flipbook can be turned into a clay animation film.

C.Choice: It solves the problems of a flipbook by showing how to make a clay animation film.

Key.Rationale: The paragraph does not discuss problems related to making a flipbook.

D.Choice: It explains the process of using a flipbook to create a clay animation film.

Key.Rationale: The paragraph does not explain how to use a flipbook to create a clay animation film.

SubTopics: Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.
Content: Read the sentence from the passage.
:box:“Each character or object is moved extremely slowly, the movement being almost invisible to the naked eye.”
What does the phrase “invisible to the naked eye” mean?

Key.Rationale: This choice does not describe the given phrase and does not make sense in the context of the passage.
This choice does not describe the given phrase and does not make sense in the context of the passage.
This choice does not describe the given phrase and does not make sense in the context of the passage.
The phrase emphasizes how imperceptible the movement of the character or object is due to it being moved so slowly.

Topics: Informational Text - Craft & Structure/Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Explain how an author uses reasons and evidence to support particular points in a text.
Content: What reason does the author give for why character sculptures are moved slowly when filming clay animation?

A.Choice: It creates the effect of slow motion.

Key.Rationale: There is no textual evidence to support this choice.

B.Choice: The clay that is used is difficult to mold.

Key.Rationale: There is no textual evidence to support this choice.

C.Choice: It makes their movements look smoother.

Key.Rationale: The author states that objects are moved slowly to “create fluid... movements...”

D.Choice: The camera is unable to capture quick movements.

Key.Rationale: There is no textual evidence to support this choice.

SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 4 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: Read the sentence from the passage.
:box:“After moving each object to its d͟e͟s͟i͟r͟e͟d position, press record again and count to one, as done in step 7, and then press record again.”
What does the word d͟e͟s͟i͟r͟e͟d mean as used in the passage?

Key.Rationale: This choice does not make sense in the given context.
The word “desired” means “preferred.”
This choice does not make sense in the given context.
The passage does not indicate that objects must be moved to a compulsory position.

Topics: Informational Text - Craft & Structure/Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Describe the overall structure (e.g., chronology, comparison, cause/effect, problem/solution) of events, ideas, concepts, or information in a text or part of a text.
Content: Which statement best describes the structure of the section “Steps” at the end of the passage?

A.Choice: The steps are listed in the order of their importance.

Key.Rationale: Although some steps may be more important than others, the steps are not presented in order of importance.

B.Choice: The steps are listed according to which materials are needed.

Key.Rationale: Although a list of needed materials is included in this section, the steps are not presented according to the materials needed.

C.Choice: The steps are listed in the order they should be completed.

Key.Rationale: The list presents information in sequential order.

D.Choice: The steps are listed according to their level of difficulty.

Key.Rationale: Although some steps may be viewed as more difficult than others, the steps are not presented by level of difficulty.

SubTopics: Determine the main idea of a text and explain how it is supported by key details; summarize the text.
Content: This question has two parts. Answer Part One and then answer Part Two.
What is the main idea of the overall passage?

A.Choice: Claymation is a well-known art that anyone can take part in.

Key.Rationale: The passage mainly tells about the art of clay animation and provides a set of directions for creating a clay animation film.

B.Choice: Claymation can be created using pencil and paper.

Key.Rationale: Flipbooks, not clay animation films, are created using paper and pencil.

C.Choice: Claymation films can take many years to create.

Key.Rationale: The fact that a claymation film may take years to create is a detail, not a main idea.

D.Choice: Claymation is featured in many movies and television shows.

Key.Rationale: The fact that claymation is featured in many movies and television shows is a detail, not a main idea.

Content: Which evidence from the passage supports the answer in Part One? Choose two answers.

A.Choice: “From that point, filmmakers around the world began to explore and grasp this technique, and in recent years this art form has become quite popular with films.”

Key.Rationale: This choice supports the idea that clay animation is a “well-known art.

B.Choice: “When the pages are flipped through in one simultaneous motion, it gives the illusion of the character raising his arm to wave 'hello.' ”

Key.Rationale: This choice does not support the main idea from Part One.

C.Choice: “With the right supplies and a lot of patience, you, too, can make your very own short claymation film.”

Key.Rationale: This choice supports the idea that “anyone can take part in” this art.

D.Choice: “Use modeling clay to create characters and objects that you will use to tell your story.”

Key.Rationale: This choice does not support the main idea from Part One.

Topics: Informational Text - Craft & Structure/Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Interpret text features (e.g., headings, graphics, charts, timelines, diagrams) and/or make connections between text and the content of text features.
Content: How does the section “Steps” connect to the rest of the passage?

A.Choice: It provides instructions for how to make a clay animation film.

Key.Rationale: The numbered list provides instructions for how to create a clay animation film.

B.Choice: It provides suggestions for how to improve a clay animation film.

Key.Rationale: The steps do not provide suggestions for how to improve a clay animation film.

C.Choice: It provides comparisons between clay animation films and other films.

Key.Rationale: The steps do not make any comparisons between clay animation films and other types of films.

D.Choice: It provides shortcuts to take when making a longer clay animation film.

Key.Rationale: The steps do not explain any shortcuts when making a clay animation film.

SubTopics: Refer to details and examples in a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: This question has two parts. Answer Part One and then answer Part Two.
Based on information from the passage, which inference can best be made about clay animation?

Key.Rationale: Although the passage states that clay animation “has become quite popular,” the passage does not provide enough information for the reader to infer that this art form is popular with children.
The passage states that it “was first seen as early as 1902.”

C.Choice: It is more realistic than a flipbook.

Key.Rationale: Although the passage does include some information about flipbooks, it does not include information that would allow the reader to infer that clay animation is more realistic than a flipbook.
Athough one could infer that creating clay animation would require artistic talent, the passage makes it seem like practice is more important than artistic talent.

Content: Which evidence from the passage supports the answer in Part One? Choose one answer.

A.Choice: “Have you ever seen an animated movie or television show that looks like everything has been made out of clay?”

Key.Rationale: This choice does not support the correct inference from Part One.

B.Choice: “This technique using clay figurines and objects is called 'claymation,' or stop-motion animation, and was first seen as early as 1902 in Georges Méliès's film...”

Key.Rationale: The sentence supports the inference that clay animation has a long history.

C.Choice: “... except oftentimes filmmakers will use figures made entirely out of clay and will use a camera to capture their footage rather than a pencil and paper.”

Key.Rationale: This choice does not support the correct inference from Part One.

D.Choice: “Sometimes this process of creating a claymation film can take years.”

Key.Rationale: This choice is related to the amount of time that creating a clay animation film may take, but it does not relate to the history of the art form.

SubTopics: Determine a theme of a story, drama, or poem from details in the text; summarize the text.
Content: Read the sentences from the passage.
:box:“I'm not like Pa. People won't like what I play. They might laugh.”
Write an essay analyzing how the sentences show a theme of the passage. Use evidence from the passage to support your response.

SubTopics: Form and use the progressive verb tenses (e.g., I was walking, I am walking, I will be walking).
Content: Read the paragraph.

:box:(1) I am watching a bird outside my window. (2) It is using sticks to build a nest in a tree. (3) It is flying up to the nest and down again. (4) Now it was picking up a string to use in the nest.
Which sentence should be revised to correct the error in verb tense?

Key.Rationale: This choice has the correct verb tense for the given paragraph.
This choice has the correct verb tense for the given paragraph.
This choice has the correct verb tense for the given paragraph.
Sentence 4 has a past progressive verb form; “was picking” needs to be changed to “is picking” to correct the error in verb tense. Then all the verbs would be in the present tense.

SubTopics: Use relative pronouns (e.g., who, whose, whom, which, that) and relative adverbs (e.g., where, when, why).
Content: Which underlined word should be changed to correct the error in pronoun usage?

A.Choice: Mary made the rocket t͟h͟a͟t flew higher than all the other rockets.

Key.Rationale: This choice uses correct relative pronouns.

B.Choice: The girl w͟h͟o just moved here from Arizona sits next to me in science class.

Key.Rationale: This choice uses correct relative pronouns.

C.Choice: Paul and his cousin played a game of chess t͟h͟a͟t lasted more than two hours.

Key.Rationale: This choice uses correct relative pronouns.

D.Choice: The teacher w͟h͟i͟c͟h taught me to play the trumpet is a member of the community band.

Key.Rationale: Te word “which” is the incorrect relative pronoun; the correct relative pronoun is “who.”

SubTopics: Produce complete sentences, recognizing and correcting inappropriate fragments and run-on sentences.
Content: Read the information.
:box:__________________________ and then camped at a beautiful park.
Choose the words that complete the sentence.

A.Choice: Went on a trip to the mountains

Key.Rationale: This group of words, when added to the given information, produces a fragment.

B.Choice: My family and I visited our cousins

Key.Rationale: This group of words, when added to the given information, creates a complete sentence.

C.Choice: My family, my friends, and I on a trip

Key.Rationale: This group of words, when added to the given information, produces a fragment.

D.Choice: Visited our cousins in the mountains

Key.Rationale: This group of words, when added to the given information, produces a fragment.

SubTopics: Use a comma before a coordinating conjunction in a compound sentence.
Content: Which sentence is punctuated correctly?

A.Choice: Pittsburgh has many museums yet my favorite, is the sports museum.

Key.Rationale: The comma is misplaced; the comma should be before the conjunction “yet” to separate the two independent clauses in a compound sentence.

B.Choice: The museum shows the history of football in Pennsylvania, but it also has quite an exhibit on baseball.

Key.Rationale: This choice has a comma separating the two independent clauses of a compound sentence.

C.Choice: The museum has an exhibit on racing and it provides information about car, and bike races.

Key.Rationale: The comma should be placed before the conjunction “and” to separate the two independent clauses in a compound sentence.

D.Choice: The museum offers a lot of different activities so visitors, are sure to have a good time.

Key.Rationale: The comma should be placed before the conjunction “so” to separate the two independent clauses in a compound sentence.
